qas.question: What occurs when traveling across a surface at a constant velocity with regard to friction?
What directly opposes the force applied to move an object across a surface?
What has to accounted for that causes no net force being the cause of constant velocity motion?

answers.text: object started with a non-zero velocity

qas.question: Who thought that applied force caused movement of an object regardless of non-zero velocity?
What equilibrium occurs in fluctuating velocity motion?
What continues to move with a zero velocity?
What started with a zero velocity?
There is much net force when what is taken into consideration?

context: A simple case of dynamic equilibrium occurs in constant velocity motion across a surface with kinetic friction. In such a situation, a force is applied in the direction of motion while the kinetic friction force exactly opposes the applied force. This results in zero net force, but since the object started with a non-zero velocity, it continues to move with a non-zero velocity. Aristotle misinterpreted this motion as being caused by the applied force. However, when kinetic friction is taken into consideration it is clear that there is no net force causing constant velocity motion.
